project.title: Mountain City - Web Video Series (@164cray network)
project.author: Scott Grocott x- @scott_grocott
project.description: Mountain City is on the island of Autopia. Autopia is a socially stratified island nation where car culture dominates daily life. The city is known for its towering skyscrapers, sprawling highways, and dense urban environment filled with neon lights and bustling streets. The story follows a lone protagonist navigating the dangerous underbelly of Mountain City, uncovering conspiracies tied to the powerful automotive families that control the city's economy and politics.
production_design: Miniature live sets with practical effects
Digital effects to enhance scale and atmosphere
Audio/Script production approach. Modeled after radio drama and 'South Park'.
It's all about the cars: custom builds, stunts, chases. Anytime we can focus on vehicles, we do. Car action first and narrative second.
car culture as worldbuilding: the social dynamics, fashion, music, and architecture are all influenced by automotive themes.
series_arc: The whole series will be in 3 acts.

Act 1 introduces the world and characters.Most of the primary action will take place in the wooded outskirts of the city,with occasional cutaways to the city for establishing various elements. The primary location is the 'A.O.K. Kampground' this camping facility is a more affordable, open to everyone (meaning all makes and models of cars). The campground,is ajacent to a giant recreational area for auto enthusiasts. Campers bring their vehicle to enjoy all kinds of auto performance activity.

Act 2 Takes our main character from the outskirts into the heart of Mountain City. Here, the protagonist uncovers deeper conspiracies involving the powerful automotive families that control the city. High-speed chases through neon-lit streets, daring escapes, and intense confrontations define this act.This culminates in a showdown with leader of the Ferrari family, revealing their plans to monopolize the city's automotive industry.

Act 3 Adds the final twist in that the city is taken over by a new more powerful boss.'Chad Boss' to be exact. Chad moves in with his Lamborghini operation (up until this point in the series Lamborghini has not be seen or spoken of because Chad had not been called in yet) and begins to battle the powers that be to get the city under his control in a high-stakes showdown that reshapes Mountain City.
characters: protagonist: friend group (from the campground) TBD
primary antagonist: Joey Tortellini (Ferrari Family Leader)

autopia.description: A large island nation in the middle of the ocean. Autopia is a socially stratified and car culture dominates daily life. A port city, an inland desert, a mountain filled northern region (The location of Mountain City), a large deep canyon region in the desert. Very mysterious
town_dessert-flat: Desert Flats.Desert Flats-sounds like this vast, sun-baked expanse just past Mountain City's edges, where the land stretches out flat and endless, dotted with wind-worn rocks and forgotten trails. It's got that lonely, timeless feel, right? The kind of place where old ranches cling to life, dust devils dance in the heat, and maybe a lone inventor tinkers in a shed full of half-finished machines.

the racing scene fits perfectly, turning those endless flats into a high-stakes playground for speed junkies and daredevils. Imagine souped-up mini hot rods barreling across the salt, kicking up dust clouds that shimmer in the heat, crowds gathered under patched-up awnings, betting on who'll make it to the end without their engine seizing from the dust.
city_bay-city: Bay City-coastal counterpart to Mountain City's inland vibes. A miniature port town. Bay's the living room, where inland and coast share space on one tiny peninsula. Mountains frame it, but the water's what makes it breathe.
Bay City-miniature coastal racing town. Drift culture rules here, with cars screeching around tight bends, drifting sideways past neon lights and harbor cranes, salt air mixing with tire smoke.
city_harbor-town: Harbor Town-Bay City's rough-and-tumble cousin. The kind of dockside sprawl where the air's thick with salt, diesel, and low-end bass. Muscle cars are kings here, their V8s rumbling like thunder off rusted freighters. This is where every car on the island continent makes landfall-creaking gangways, tarps flapping in the salt wind. Cars roll down planks straight into the grit, tires hissing against wet concrete, grease and sweat in the air as mechanics and drivers size each other up before the first race even starts.
town_canyon-crossing: Canyon Crossing-that's the wild frontier carved into Autopia's craggy spine. Imagine endless red rock canyons, wide enough to swallow whole RV convoys and dotted with switchback trails where 4x4s claw their way up sheer cliffs, tires spitting gravel and dust. It's a haven for off-road junkies, those rugged souls who live for the roar of a big-block diesel echoing off canyon walls, the thrill of jumping ravines in tricked-out rigs. Picture massive campfires under star-drenched skies, RVs parked in half-moon clusters like tiny pioneer settlements, and dust trails marking the paths of the latest canyon daredevils. This is where sanity takes a backseat to the pull of the wild
town_everglades-jungle: Everglades Jungle-the humid, pulse-quickening heart of Autopia's night scene, a twisted mashup of tangled mangroves, glowing neon, and full-moon key to key style small connected island races.

dealershipFamilies.description: Each ethnic family owns a dealership + restaurant tied to national cuisine and car manufacturer. Economic and political dynasties shape Mountain City culture. Families control both racing fleets (performance-focused basics) and showroom collections (premium status symbols).
dealershipFamilies.coreRule: Family last names correspond to national cuisine; manufacturer matches origin country. Each family monopolizes their brand across all quality tiers.

workingClass.description: Regular citizens of Autopia who drive unlicensed fantasy cars not affiliated with any dealership family. These are the true independents - the working class, the nobodies, the underdogs.
workingClass.vehicleTypes: Hot Wheels originals (Bone Shaker, Twin Mill, Deora II), Matchbox generics (unlicensed trucks, vans, service vehicles), Maisto fantasy models
workingClass.socialStatus: Lowest tier - no family protection, no brand loyalty, must earn all respect
workingClass.locations: A.O.K. Kampground (accepts all makes/models), independent shops, alleys, back streets
workingClass.narrativeRole: Ultimate underdogs - when an unlicensed car wins a race, it's a major upset that threatens the family power structure

1_64_scale_dicast_brands.brief_history: Founded in 1968 by Mattel co-founder Elliot Handler in the USA to rival Matchbox; revolutionized 1:64 diecast with fast, stylized 'hot rod' designs and orange tracks. Acquired Matchbox in 1997; produces billions annually, blending toys and collectibles.

Launched in 1953 by Lesney Products in the UK as pocket-sized diecast toys; acquired by Mattel in 1997 after Lesney's 1982 bankruptcy. Known for realistic vehicles; shifted production to Asia in the 1980s.
Founded in 1961 in France by Jean Sablon; focuses on everyday and emergency vehicles. Acquired by Migao Group (China) in 2017; emphasizes play value with durable designs.
Established in 1967 in Hong Kong as May Cheong; Maisto brand debuted in 1990 for affordable diecast. Acquired Bburago in 2005; produces budget-friendly replicas with global licensing.
Founded in 2002 in the USA by Kevin Davey; specializes in licensed pop culture and muscle car replicas. Known for high-detail blister-pack series; targets adult collectors.
Launched in 1998 in Hong Kong by Gateway; pioneered composite (ABS + diecast) for precision. Associated with UT Models; focuses on premium exotics and racers.
Founded in 1999 in California by Jack and May Li; started with Thunder Crusher trucks, exploded with DUB City urban customs. Acquired by Simba Dickie Group in 2021; blends toys and collectibles.
Started in 1982 by JRI Inc. in New Jersey, USA; focused on 1950s-60s American classics. Acquired by Jakks Pacific in 1995; emphasized detail in blister packs.
Debuted in 1969 by Topper Toys in the USA as speed-focused rivals to Hot Wheels; revived in 1994 by Playing Mantis, then RC2/Tomy (discontinued 2013). Relaunched by Round 2 in 2016.
Founded in 2007 in California by Chris Leong (ex-Muscle Machines); targets overlooked 1950s-70s American iron with high detail. Emphasizes full-metal construction.
Established in 2014 in Hong Kong by car enthusiasts; specializes in JDM and race cars. Gained traction with hobby-grade details; partners with iXO for partworks.
Launched mid-2010s as a 1:64 line of TrueScale Miniatures (founded 2006 in Hong Kong by Glen Chou); focuses on exotics and JDM with full diecast bodies. Affordable premium alternative.
Founded in 2000 in France by Hugo Ripert (ex-Vitesse/Ixo); pioneered affordable resin racers, especially Le Mans backmarkers. Expanded to diecast; produced in China/Madagascar.
Started in 1992 in Australia by Trevor and Bev Young as a Kyosho distributor; began own production in 1998. Specializes in Aussie V8 Supercars; changed hands post-2006.
Founded in 1963 in Japan; pioneered RC models, entered diecast in 1992. Known for high-end replicas; licenses BMW exclusively for dealership sales.
Established in 2000 in China as a plastic toy maker; pivoted to licensed RC/diecast by 2005. Holds global BMW RC exclusivity; focuses on affordable replicas.
Founded in 1979 in Hong Kong; shifted production to China in the 1980s. Budget-friendly with pullback motors; licenses 40+ brands for global distribution.
Launched 1974 in Italy as Martoys by Besana brothers (ex-Mebetoys); renamed 1976. Pioneered 1:18 diecast; bankrupt 2005, revived by Maisto in 2007.
Debuted 1970 in Japan by Takara (now Tomy); emphasizes realistic JDM vehicles. Limited Vintage line adds premium details; huge domestic following.
Founded mid-2010s in Hong Kong; niche for modified JDM and LB Works customs. High-detail resin/diecast hybrids; popular in Asia-Pacific collector scene.
Launched early 2010s in Hong Kong; affordable racers and tuners. Gained cult status for quick releases; focuses on endurance and GT cars.
Founded 1946 in Germany by Richard Siewer; post-WWII focus on farm/commercial vehicles. Family-owned; emphasizes durable, realistic toys.
Established 1953 in France; revived 2000s after bankruptcy. Specializes in French classics; high-detail resin/diecast for collectors.
Founded 1956 in the UK by Mettoy; aviation roots. Acquired by Hornby in 1980s; focuses on licensed racers and milestones.
Started 1912 in Germany as Schreyer & Co.; post-WWII diecast revival. Premium German engineering focus; owned by Simba Dickie since 1990s.
Founded 2000s in Hong Kong; niche for rare prototypes and concepts. Resin-focused with diecast accents; small-batch for enthusiasts.
Launched 2010s in China; hyper-detailed exotics and tuners. Affordable premium; rapid growth via online collector communities.
Early 2010s USA brand; custom lowriders and street rods. Collaborates with artists; emphasizes ride height and stance.
Founded 2010s in Hong Kong; JDM stance and drift focus. Diecast with resin parts; popular for modified Skylines and Silvias.
Mid-2010s Chinese newcomer; budget racers and hypercars. Quick iterations; appeals to entry-level premium collectors.
Revival line from 2000s under Tomica; reissues vintage Japanese classics with modern details. Collector-exclusive.
Founded 1976 in Japan; JDM and Super GT specialist. Bankrupt 2020s but legacy endures via reissues; high-fidelity racers.
Started 1950s in USA as slot car maker; diecast since 2000s. Acquired by Round 2; muscle car focus.
Founded 2005 in USA; revives classics like Johnny Lightning. Parent to Auto World; emphasizes nostalgia.
